speaker: jolly
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil and joining me today is Dan who is looking very jolly.

speaker: Dan
text: Of course I'm looking jolly – meaning happy and smiley; it's my favourite time of the year.

speaker: Neil
text: Ah yes, all that food, all those presents, all that fun.

speaker: Dan
text: Forget the food and fun – Christmas is all about the presents!

speaker: spirit
text: I'm not sure that's quite the spirit – the real meaning of something.

speaker: Dan
text: Well, Neil, I was actually talking about giving presents, not getting them.

speaker: Neil
text: Ah sorry, Dan, I misjudged you. As you enjoy giving presents so much, I'm very pleased to have you with me in this 6 Minute English – Our topic… What makes the perfect Santa? We'll have 6 items of vocabulary for you and, of course, our quiz question. Ready?

speaker: Dan
text: Hit me.

speaker: Neil
text: How many Santas are there in the world?

speaker: Neil
text: c) 15 million

speaker: Dan
text: I know there are a lot but 15 million must be wrong; 1,500 seems too few, so I'll go for 15,000.

speaker: candidate
text: We'll see if you're right at the end of the programme. Dan, you seem like a strong candidate for a job as Santa. Ever considered it?

speaker: Dan
text: I'd love to! A candidate is a person competing for a job.

speaker: Neil
text: And what do you think is a key part of being Santa – or Father Christmas as we also call him in the UK?

speaker: Dan
text: You've already mentioned being jolly…

speaker: Neil
text: I have. Let's listen to James Lovell, who runs a Santa school at his company Ministry of Fun in London. What does he say is the key?

speaker: James Lovell
text: A perfect 'ho ho ho!' is a key part of being a Father Christmas. It's a ho ho ho! And it needs to just reinforce the fact that you are the jolliest person on the planet. So I like to reach down into my tummy, tap it and with a big smile on my face go ho ho hoooo!

speaker: reinforce
text: The perfect ho ho ho! You need that to reinforce the fact you are the jolliest person in the world.

speaker: Dan
text: To reinforce means to make something stronger. Ho ho ho!

speaker: Neil
text: Wow, Dan! You're very convincing. Are you sure you've never done this before?

speaker: Dan
text: I haven't but I want to. It feels good! Ho ho ho!

speaker: Neil
text: I could be the ideal career move for you, Dan. But I bet it's not all fun.

speaker: pressure
text: Hmm, maybe. I think there would be a lot of pressure to perform. Pressure is the feeling of worry you can get when you are expected to deal with a difficult situation.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, think of all the children you have to impress. Pressure indeed. Let's hear from James Lovell again, who runs a Santa school in London.

speaker: Portrayingrecreate
text: Portraying Father Christmas is not an easy job because when you're dressed as Father Christmas, you have a huge responsibility to recreate the magic of the real Santa in every way. You need to look good, you need to have lots to say and you need to be incredibly jolly and you need to have magical eyes.

speaker: portraying
text: So it seems I was right: portraying Father Christmas is not an easy job. Portraying meaning playing the part of – like an actor does.

speaker: recreate
text: He says there's a huge responsibility to recreate the magic of the real Santa. To recreate means to make something exist again.

speaker: Dan
text: All those kids expecting that magical moment – and it's all down to you as Santa! Hmm I'm beginning to have second thoughts about this career change…

speaker: Neil
text: Could you handle the pressure?

speaker: Dan
text: I'm not sure I could! Portraying Father Christmas might be a challenge too far – despite my ho ho ho!

speaker: Neil
text: Now it's time to find out the answer to our quiz question. I asked how many Santas there are in the world?

speaker: Neil
text: c) 15 million

speaker: Dan
text: I said b) 15,000

speaker: Neil
text: And you were… wrong! I'm afraid it was a trick question – there is, of course, only one Santa!

speaker: Dan
text: Ahhh that's not fair!

speaker: Neil
text: Sorry! Shall we have a recap of the vocabulary?

speaker: Dan
text: Yes please – that would make me jolly again.

speaker: Neil
text: Jolly, meaning happy and smiley. What makes you jolly, Dan?

speaker: Dan
text: Christmas of course! Now Neil, I have to say, cheating me out of that quiz question was really not in the spirit of 6 Minute English. We are always nice to each other.

speaker: Neil
text: Ah yes, you're probably right. Spirt here has the sense of something's real meaning. The spirit of 6 Minute English is friendly educational fun – not cheating your colleagues!

speaker: Dan
text: Glad we've got that straight. Our next word is candidate. Until you made me think about how hard it is to be a good Santa, I thought I'd be a strong candidate for the job.

speaker: Neil
text: A candidate is a person competing for a job. Next we had reinforce.

speaker: Dan
text: Reinforce means to make something stronger. Repeating the vocabulary in 6 Minute English reinforces your ability to remember it!

speaker: Neil
text: That's right – and it puts you under less pressure when you're speaking English if you have a good range of vocabulary.

speaker: Dan
text: Pressure is the feeling of worry you can get when you are expected to deal with a difficult situation – like pretending to be Santa! Yes there's a lot of pressure involved in portraying someone else.

speaker: Neil
text: Portraying, meaning playing the part of someone – like an actor does. It can be very difficult to get it right.

speaker: Dan
text: Yep, it's a real skill to be able to recreate the look and character of another person. Recreate meaning to make something exist again.

speaker: Neil
text: Well we'll try our best to recreate a positive learning experience for you all next time on 6 Minute English. Until then don't forget to check out our YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages. Goodbye!

speaker: Dan
text: Goodbye!
